body: TWO months ago the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, overseers of the sprawling industrial park on the East River, inaugurated its own steam production system, enabling it to provide steam to its tenants at rates below those of Consolidated Edison. On its agenda for 1983 are further development of plans for a permanent co-generation plant
title: Real Estate; Brooklyn Navy Yard Program

body: Sixty people were arrested or given summonses yesterday in a police sweep of a six-block area in Brooklyn. Charges ranged from the sale of narcotics to drinking in public. The police said the area - Fulton Street in the Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant sections - was picked for a sweep because of community complaints about crime. THE CITY
title: THE CITY; Police Sweep

body: Bernard King remembers the first time he saw a game in Madison Square Garden, nearly 10 years ago. He had always been too busy ''playing my own games'' to visit basketball's most famous arena, but when he was a senior at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn he was honored as an all-city player between halves of a Knick game. title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; BERNARD KING COMES HOME

body: The Justice Department said yesterday that it intended to parole 49 illegal Haitian aliens who had been detained in Brooklyn for from nine to 13 months while their applications for legal admission into the United States were pending. The 49 had not been covered by the ruling of a Federal court in Miami in June that called for parole of 1,774 other
title: U.S. MOVES TO PAROLE 49 HAITIANS HELD IN BROOKLYN

body: A year ago, J. Daniel Selig, an architectural historian, joined the flock of transplanted Manhattanites who dominate Jersey City's brownstone-renovation movement in historic neighborhoods near the Hudson River. But besides the rows of grand, old homes, Mr. Selig has taken delight in studying the architectural variety in the churches of his new
title: VIEWING THE SPIRES OF JERSEY CITY

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: The resignation of Frederick W. Richmond from the House of Representatives has left three minority-group candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for his seat in the newly drawn 11th Congressional District in Brooklyn. The district was approved by the Justice Department during the recent reapportionment process as a district where either a
title: 3 MINORITY CANDIDATES SEEK RICHMOND'S SEAT

body: Lunch for a Cause I n Brooklyn's Fort Greene section this morning, at least 100 business and professional people know exactly where their next meal is coming from: Lunchtime will bring a chicken dinner, delivered for $3 by some other people mobilizing for a voice in where their next housing is coming from. Cooking started last night at the
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Charley Pride, the country music singer, will give two concerts at Waterloo Village in Stanhope on Saturday. The first will be at 5 P.M.; the second, four hours later. Mr. Pride won two Grammy awards in 1971, when the album ''Did You Think to Pray?'' was named best sacred performance and his single record, ''Let Me Live,'' was chosen best gospel
title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE; PRIDE AT STANHOPE

body: Twenty-one students and a teacher were robbed at gunpoint yesterday in their fourth-floor classroom at Brooklyn Technical High School by two young men. According to a police spokesman, Officer Frank Dunne, the two entered the room during an English class and ordered the teacher and the students to place their money and other valuables on the desks.
title: THE CITY; Gunmen Rob Class At Brooklyn Tech

body: Over cheesecake at Junior's, a Brooklyn restaurant, Daniel Greenbaum and Allen Handelman sealed their real estate partnership in January 1981. They agreed to seek out Brooklyn properties for rehabilitation and resale as cooperatives. Mr. Greenbaum, now 27 years old, graduated from Boston University's law school two years ago and promptly became a
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; BROOKLYN REHABILITATION ENTERPRENEURS

title: BLACK CRIME, BLACK VICTIMS

body: Fresh lumber was being carried into brownstone basements and power tools were droning out open windows in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section yesterday as residents and visitors strolled the sunny streets, at once celebrating historic treasures and current creative vitality. In a house tour of the area, which has been a landmark district since 1978, the
title: FORT GREENE'S DWELLERS CELEBRATE ITS TREASURES

body: The fourth Exhibition of Black Women Artists of Brooklyn and Environs will be at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, through May 2. More than 200 works by 53 artists are on display. The exhibition, sponsored by Cultural Crossroads, a four-year-old Fort Greene-Clinton Hills
title: Black Female Artists To Present Exhibition

body: Fort Greene House Tour, departing from Williamsburg Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, 643-1603. This tour will explore two historic neighborhoods of Brooklyn - the Brooklyn Academy of Music Triangle and Fort Greene. Twelve houses will be seen, on Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. Tickets $4 in advance, $5 on Sunday. Flatbush Victorian House Tour, de-
title: ANTIQUES, ORCHIDS AND HOUSE TOURS

body: In October 1969, at the height of his campaign for re-election, Mayor John V. Lindsay unveiled a spectacular plan for the revitalization of downtown Brooklyn. When the campaign ended, most of the plan was forgotten. But one part survives, and some would say thrives. It is the Fulton Street Mall. The mall has not transformed downtown Brooklyn, nor
title: MALL STANDS ALONE IN BROOKLYN 'RENAISSANCE'

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. But a b orough-byborough survey
title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY

body: In school he was a failure - a chronic truant from the time he was in kindergarten, for years unable to read because no one noticed he needed glasses. But out on the street, dressed in cashmere coats and $150 shoes, he made his mark as the self-styled general of an army of muggers. They called him ''Peewee'' because he was so short, but by the time
title: AT 15, TRUANT ENDS A TRAIL OF CRIME WITH A SLAYING; Juvenile Crime First of six articles on the han-dling of delinquents by the schools, the courts and the po-lice, and on some new ap-; proaches to the problems.

body: Faced with increasing attacks on doctors and other employees, New York City hospitals have stepped up security measures in the last several months. The most recent reported attacks on doctors occurred at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section. A resident physician was stabbed on a stairway Sunday morning in an attempted robbery. On
title: HOSPITALS IN CITY INCREASING SECURITY

body: A resident physician who had just finished examining a patient at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section was stabbed on a stairway at 6:45 A.M. yesterday in an attempted robbery, according to the police. The doctor, 25-year-old Geraldo Platovsky, suffered a ''puncture'' wound in the lower right abdomen, according to Samuel Sanderson,
title: Assailant Stabs Doctor In a Brooklyn Hospital
